data.title: In Ukraine, Trump and Kellogg must avoid the road to Yalta
data.description:
It is increasingly clear that retired Army Lt. Gen. Keith Kellogg does not yet have an overall plan to end the war in Ukraine â€” at least not one that President Trump is willing to support.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Megyn Kelly last Friday that theÂ Trump administration believesÂ the war has been fought to a â€œstalemate,â€ and that â€œit is not going to end with the maximalist goals of eitherâ€ Russia or Ukraine.

Russian President Vladimir Putin disagrees. He remains dead-set on the total destruction of Ukraine and continues to insist on its absolute submission. His advisor,Â Nikolai Patrushev, went further: â€œIt canâ€™t be ruled out that Ukraine will cease to exist at all in the coming year.â€

The Kremlin believes time is now on its side, especially now that TrumpÂ has tasked KelloggÂ with finding a negotiated solution in 100 days or less.Â 

A quick negotiated solution means ending the war on Putinâ€™s terms. Moscow is still demanding Ukraineâ€™s complete capitulation â€” territorial concessions, Ukrainian neutrality, and unilateral disarmament.

Putin is also insistingÂ that Ukraine would have to â€œgive up its pursuit of NATO membershipâ€ and accept â€œextensive limitations on the size of its armed forces and on the kinds of weapons systems it is allowed to possess.â€Â 

Each of these is a non-starter for Ukraine.

Essentially, Putin is demanding Kellogg embark on an ill-advised road to a modern-dayÂ Yalta Conference.Â Near the end of World War II, President Franklin Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill effectively conceded Eastern Europe at Yalta to Soviet leader Josef Stalin in exchange for Stalin agreeing to fight Japan.Â The result? Forty-three years of theÂ Iron CurtainÂ in Europe.

Kellogg needs to channel his inner Gen. George Patton and tell Trump that he is on a road to nowhere with Putin.

The Kremlin is betting on Trump being strategically distracted in the Indo-Pacific â€” as Roosevelt was at the end of World War II â€” and getting everything he wants in Eastern Europe and in the Caucasian nations of Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia. Putin has made no secret about it.Â 

Russia has repeatedly rejected the Kellogg proposal toÂ freeze the war. Moscow will not accept the presence ofÂ European peace-keeping forcesÂ in Ukraine. And despite the Ukrainian Constitution saying otherwise, Putin considers Zelensky anÂ illegitimate leader,Â since his presidential term expired last year. As a consequence, he will not negotiate directly with him.

It is therefore ill-advised for Kellogg toÂ urge UkraineÂ to hold elections after any ceasefire. Moscow is performing poorly on the battlefield but excels at election interference. Recent elections inÂ Moldova,Â GeorgiaÂ and RomaniaÂ are highly dispositive, a foreshadowing of what would come.Â 

Meanwhile, Putin is continuing his assault on Ukraine.

Over the weekend, Russia launched ballisticÂ missiles onÂ Odesaâ€™s historic city center, a UNESCO designated World Heritage site. Multiple historic buildings were damaged and seven people were injured.Â Norwegian diplomatsÂ visiting the city narrowly escaped the strikes. In March 2024, Greek Prime MinisterÂ Kyriakos MitsotakisÂ also avoided a missile strike in Odesa within 500 meters of his convoy.

Kellogg, for now, is struggling to set conditions for any meaningful negotiations. Putin is clearly waiting for a face-to-face meeting with Trump in what he hopes becomes a second Yalta-like conference.

Wittingly or not, Kellogg is trapped in a Monty Hall-like â€œLetâ€™s Make a Dealâ€ modus operandi of his own making â€” as opposed to a more forceful â€œthis is what you are going to doâ€ approach to Putin and his cronies in the Kremlin. This peace deal is more in the short-term interests of the U.S. and not the victim â€” Ukraine.

Presently, Kellogg has no negotiating leverage. There are signs that may change. On Monday, Trump announced that he wantsÂ Ukraine to repay the U.S.Â with rare earth minerals valued at â€œclose to $300 billion.â€ Kellogg would be wise to remind Trump that parts of the illegally Russian-occupied Donbas are rich in natural resources.

Indeed,Â the DonbasÂ â€œharbors some of the worldâ€™s largest reserves of titanium and iron ore, fields of untapped lithium and massive deposits of coal. Collectively, they are worth tens of trillions of dollars.â€Â 

So Ukraine is more than capable of paying its way forward. It is time Kellogg reminded Putin of that reality.

But Putin will only get that message to the extent that his nose is bloodied on the battlefield. He survived Bidenâ€™s â€œjust enoughâ€ war in Ukraine, and now he believes he can outlast Trump.Â 

Kellogg can disabuse Putin of that notion by empowering the Armed Forces of Ukraine to take the fight to the Russians, and to do so now.

Russia has been severely militarily weakened. After nearly three years of war, Putin has sufferedÂ an estimated 841,660 casualtiesÂ â€”Â 48,240Â in January alone â€” and combined tens of thousands of tanks, armored fighting vehicles, artillery systems, multiple rocket launch systems, aircraft, helicopters, warships, and vehicles.

The only way for Kellogg to create decisive negotiating leverage and stop the killing in Ukraine is to defeat Russia and drive it out of the country. That involves the use of all the instruments on national power: diplomatic, information, military and economy, or DIME.Â 

New sanctions, coordinating with OPEC to drive down the cost of oil, and targeting shadow fleets alone will not bring Putin to the negotiation table. The hammer â€” the punch to the face â€” must come from the military instrument of national power. While Ukraine is effectively targeting oil refineries, they must take pressure off their front-line units in the close fight, and that requires interdiction.

This entails targeting Russian, North Korean and Chechen forces, their equipment, weapons, ammunition, fuel, supplies in Russia before they enter Ukraine. It means targeting them in their assembly areas, at the seaports, airports, and railheads, ammunition storage areas and fuel depots. Only when Putin feels threatened with the loss of his army will he come to the negotiation table â€” sanctions will not do that.

Putin will negotiate with Kellogg, but only when he is made to realize he has truly lost on the battlefields of Ukraine.

Anything less, and it is likely Yalta 2.0 whenever Putin and Trump meet. And a new Iron Curtain will fall.Â 

Col. (Ret.)Â Jonathan SweetÂ served 30 years as a military intelligence officer.Â Mark TothÂ writes on national security and foreign policy.Â

data.title: Morning Report â€” Trump: U.S. should â€˜take overâ€™ Gaza
data.description:
Editorâ€™s note: The Hillâ€™sÂ MorningÂ ReportÂ is our daily newsletter that dives deep into Washingtonâ€™s agenda. To subscribe,Â click hereÂ or fill out the box below.

In todayâ€™s issue:Â Â 

  • Trump floats â€œlong-term ownershipâ€ of GazaÂ Strip
  • Bondi confirmed as Trump Cabinet takes shape
  • Senate GOP in the lead on budgeting

The U.S. should take over the Gaza Strip, President Trump suggested on Tuesday, and thereby evict around 2.2 million Palestinians as the U.S. rebuilds the enclave.

At a White House press conference with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Trump said the U.S. should be responsible for clearing the territory of rubble and unexploded bombs and proposing an â€œeconomic development that will supply unlimited numbers of jobs and housing for the people of the area.â€

â€œThe U.S. will take over the Gaza Strip, and we will do a job with it,â€ Trump said. â€œWeâ€™ll own it and be responsible for dismantling all the dangerous unexploded bombs and other weapons on the site, level the site and get rid of the destroyed buildings, level it out, create an economic development that will supply unlimited numbers of jobs and housing for the people of the area.â€

The presidentâ€™s remarks â€” during which he called his plans for Gaza â€œthe Riviera of the Middle Eastâ€ â€” are some of his most extreme proposals regarding the future of the 141-square-mile territory where nearly 2 million Palestinians live and hope to be part of a future Palestinian state.Â 

Since Hamasâ€™s Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel and the subsequent war in Gaza, more than 47,000 Palestinians have been killed, and a vast majority of Gazaâ€™s population has been internally displaced. Trump said the Palestinians who have lived in Gaza have â€œlived a miserable existence.â€ He suggested other countries invest millions of dollars to create â€œnumerous sites or one large siteâ€ where Palestinians could relocate.

Netanyahu â€” who during the press conference called Trump â€œthe greatest friend Israel has ever had in the White Houseâ€ â€” said that he was open to the idea.

â€œYou say things others refuse to say and after the jaws drop, people scratch their heads and they say, â€˜You know, heâ€™s right,â€™â€ Netanyahu said. â€œPresident Trump is taking it to a much higher level. â€¦ He sees a different future for that piece of land. Itâ€™s worth paying attention to this. Weâ€™re talking about it. Itâ€™s something that could change history.â€

â–ª The New York Times: With his Gaza plan, an unbound Trump pushes an improbable idea.

â–ª The Associated Press: Aid is surging into Gaza under the ceasefire. Is it helping?

â–ª ABC News: Why shutting down USAID could have major impacts on Gaza aid.

The president on Tuesday suggested the U.S. would develop the land but gave no details about who would be allowed to live there, referring multiple times to â€œthe worldâ€™s people.â€ The idea appears to build on Trumpâ€™s 2020 peace plan that envisioned Gazaâ€™s coastline developed for commercial and leisure resorts. The plan was developed by Trumpâ€™s son-in-law Jared Kushner, whose background is in real estate development.Â 

Asked about the possibility of sending U.S. troops to Gaza, Trump said the U.S. will â€œdo what is necessaryâ€ as he laid out plans for the U.S. to take the area over in â€œa long-term ownership position,â€ and he suggested he would visit the territory.Â 

Gaza is not a sovereign land and is considered under international law to be occupied territory.

â€œA U.S. invasion of Gaza would lead to the slaughter of thousands of U.S. troops and decades of war in the Middle East,â€ Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) wrote on the social platform X. â€œItâ€™s like a bad, sick joke.â€

â–ª NBC News: â€œDerangedâ€ and â€œproblematicâ€: Bipartisan lawmakers bash Trumpâ€™s Gaza proposal.

â–ª Politico: Trumpâ€™s Gaza plan sparks backlash in the Middle East.

The proposal underscores Trumpâ€™s broad approach to the region and appears to give little consideration to what Palestinians have said they want. Gazans generally want to stay on their land, and neighboring Arab nations have fiercely opposed handing over territory because they do not want to aid an Israeli expulsion of Palestinians. Neighboring Egypt and Jordan have resisted Trumpâ€™s attempts to convince them to take in Palestinians during the reconstruction of Gaza, a process he has said could take 10 or 15 years. The Geneva Convention bars mass forcible transfers of populations.

â€œOur Palestinian people, and the people of Gaza in particular, are rooted here and will not go anywhere,â€ Mustafa Ibrahim, a Gaza-based political expert, wrote on Facebook. â€œIf Trump wants to pave something, he can go pave the sea.â€

The Hillâ€™s Laura Kelly has five key takeaways from the joint news conference.

Netanyahu also gave credit to Trump for the ceasefire deal in Gaza ahead of former President Biden, whose team â€” along with mediators from Qatar and Egypt â€” spearheaded the negotiations over many months. Trumpâ€™s Middle East adviser, Steve Witkoff, joined the talks in their final phase.

Mediators are beginning talks on phase two of the three-phase ceasefire deal that is expected to go into effect on March 1 â€” although that deadline can be extended as long as both Israel and Hamas are engaged in talks. But Trump said he doubted whether the Palestinian Authority, the ruling body in the West Bank, could administer Gaza.

â€œWell itâ€™s had a pretty hard time wouldnâ€™t you say?â€ he said. â€œIâ€™d say itâ€™s had a pretty bad time of it.â€

SMART TAKE with NewsNationâ€™s BLAKE BURMAN:

Hereâ€™s some video you donâ€™t see every day, perhaps ever. NewsNationâ€™s Ali Bradley reports the Mexican cartels are now turning to weaponized drones, and even using them on each other.Â Â Â 

Ali told me the other day that cartels authorized the use of weaponized drones at the southern border. Her report caught the attention of Rep. Glenn Ivey (D-Md.). â€œThatâ€™s not surprising to hear that after what you saw happened with Ukraine, and especially with the Hamas attacks in Israel,â€ he told me.Â 

Youâ€™ve likely heard a good amount about the cartels recently. Prepare to hear a lot more. The cartels are a focus of President Trump and his team, and the administration recently labeled them as foreign terrorist organizations.Â Â Â 

â€œTo the cartels: All options are on the table. We will secure our border,â€ Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth warned in Texas on Monday.Â Â 

Burman hosts â€œThe Hillâ€ weeknights, 6p/5c on NewsNation.Â 

3 THINGS TO KNOW TODAY:

â–ª The administration flew 10 â€œhigh-threatâ€ migrants from Texas to GuantÃ¡namo Bay Naval Base prison Tuesday, officials said, suggesting the male detainees are associated with a Venezuelan gang.

â–ª Chinaâ€™s DeepSeek artificial intelligence company poses U.S. data privacy and national security concerns. Australia on Tuesday banned DeepSeek from all government devices because of security worries.Â 

â–ª At least 20,000 federal workers have signed up ahead of a Feb. 6 deadline to exit government service in exchange for paychecks offered through September. The Trump administrationâ€™s buyout pitch to civil servants appears to have attracted about 1 percent of the eligible workforce.Â 

LEADING THE DAYÂ 

Â© The Associated Press | Rod Lamkey, Jr.

TRUMPâ€™S CABINET is taking shape as suspense ebbs about whether the Senate will confirm some of the presidentâ€™s most controversial choices, likely next week.

The full Senate on Tuesday confirmed former Florida prosecutor Pam Bondi as attorney general and Republican Doug Collins, a former House member from Georgia, to be secretary of the Veterans Affairs Department.Â 

Both Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Tulsi Gabbard narrowly cleared Senate panels Tuesday that evaluated their fitness to lead the Health and Human Services Department and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, respectively. Republican senators on the fence about Trumpâ€™s picks announced they were satisfied and would offer support to forward the two former Democrats to the full Senate, where theyâ€™re likely to button up confirmations, handing the president additional evidence that he holds early sway over his party.

â–ª The Hill: The Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee on Tuesday approved Kennedyâ€™s nomination by a vote of 14-13. Committee member Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.), a physician, said Tuesday he now backs Kennedy after the nominee and the Trump administration committed to protecting vaccines. In a speech, Cassidy said the nominee and the White House pledged to maintain a key federal vaccine advisory board, work within the current vaccine approval and safety system and allow Cassidy to provide input about department hiring decisions.

â–ª The Hill: The Senate Intelligence Committee voted 9-8 along party lines to send Gabbardâ€™s nomination to the floor for a vote. Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) said Monday that her concerns about the former Hawaii House member were overcome during their conversations.Â 

Hours after the committee voted on Gabbard, the CIA offered so-called buyouts, equivalent to eight months of pay and benefits, to its workforce, a CIA spokesperson said, the latest move by the Trump administration to overhaul the federal government and following a push against employees at the FBI and elsewhere. Some CIA personnel â€” including those handling high-priority tasks â€” will not be eligible for the offer. The Senate confirmed CIA Director John Ratcliffe two weeks ago.

Is Trump steamrolling Congress, as NBC News reports? Or are House Democrats rising up to push back with anti-Trump resistance, as Axios described?

One sure sign of opposition emerged in the form of a raft of lawsuits filed by FBI agents, public sector unions, representatives of older Americans and liberal-leaning legal groups challenging laws tied to Trumpâ€™s actions. The president and his advisers envisioned at the outset theyâ€™d face lawsuits over the constitutional order, checks and balances and the foundersâ€™ vision of the separation of powers. They believe the conservative majority on the Supreme Court is likely to support Trumpâ€™s executive say-so.

FBI agents are suing the administration to try to block efforts to gather a list of all agents assigned to probe Jan. 6, 2021, cases for fear that such a roster would be used to target and fire them. Trump has described the rioters at the Capitol as â€œhostagesâ€ and â€œpatriotsâ€ and pardoned them.

Lawmakers in both parties are troubled by the legally dubious manner in which Trump adviser and billionaire Elon Musk, designated by the president as a â€œspecial government employee,â€ is carrying out his mission to slash federal spending, purge civil servants and shrink the size of the bureaucracy â€” but Republicans in Congress say itâ€™s necessary to root out waste, fraud and abuse. In other words, they embrace the advertised â€œefficiencyâ€ goal.

The Washington Post: U.S. government officials privately warn that Muskâ€™s blitz appears illegal.

Muskâ€™s weekend targeting of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), its personnel and the NGOs with which it contracts around the world resulted in a State Department takeover of the independent agency. On Tuesday, CBS News reported that those serving in USAID missions overseas were told to shut down operations and all staff were recalled to the United States by Friday. New USAID Deputy Administrator Peter Marocco told State Department leaders Tuesday that if they did not comply, they would be evacuated by the U.S. military, according to CBS.Â 

â–ª The Hill: Musk sets himself on a collision course with lawmakers.Â 

â–ª The New York Times: Inside Muskâ€™s aggressive incursion into the federal government.

â–ª The Atlantic: Muskâ€™s bureaucratic coup is underway.

To date, Trump has publicly blessed Muskâ€™s abrasive, bullying efforts, backed by a small team Musk handpicked from his various companies, to drill deep into detailed computer data at the Office of Personnel Management, penetrate the sensitive payment system at the Treasury Department, impound funds appropriated by Congress and push civil servants to quit, retire or be fired.

The Hill: Muskâ€™s expansive portfolio divides Trump world.

Trump says Muskâ€™s actions are approved by the White House and will be overseen for any conflicts of interest. The president, who is busy challenging statutes, oversight, investigative bodies and the courts, did not explain whose oversight holds sway. House Democrats, narrowly in the minority, want to investigate Muskâ€™s authority and his teamâ€™s actions.Â Â Â Â Â Â 

The New York Times: Because of fentanyl shipments out of Asia and scant customs inspection, the United States Postal Service temporarily stopped accepting packages from China and Hong Kong on Tuesday, hours after a Trump order took effect that ended duty-free handling of many parcels.

Protests: Today, demonstrators opposed to the Trump agenda are poised for what they call â€œ50 Statesâ€ protests at capitals, including Washington, D.C. Online through Instagram, Reddit, Bluesky, Discord, Signal and a website at 50501movement.carrd.co, the â€œrejectionâ€ events are advertised.Â 

WHERE AND WHEN

  • The House will convene at 10 a.m.Â 
  • The Senate meets at 10:30 a.m.Â 
  • Vice President Vance reportedly will meet with Netanyahu today.
  • Secretary of State Marco Rubio is in Guatemala City, Guatemala, where he will meet cabinet ministers this morning before holding a joint press availability with President Bernardo Arevalo. The secretary will meet this afternoon with U.S. Embassy employees and families before participating in a â€œcriminal migrant repatriationâ€ and â€œfentanyl seizure engagementâ€ in Guatemala City.

ZOOM IN

Â© The Associated Press | J. Scott Applewhite

SHUTDOWN WATCH: The possibility of a government shutdown next month is growing as Democrats and Trump square off over efforts to freeze funding and Republicans battle amongst themselves over strategy and the size of potential cuts. The Hillâ€™s Aris Folley and Mike Lillis report the timeline is slipping for negotiators to hash out a bipartisan deal on how to fund the government, and Democrats are signaling more trouble ahead for spending talks as leaders see an opportunity in the March 14 deadline.

As House Republicans remain deadlocked, Senate Budget Committee Chair Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) will brief Republican senators today about taking the lead on a budget resolution to lay the groundwork for a package that could pass the Senate with a simple majority. Graham and other Republican senators are eager to get started on phase one of Trumpâ€™s agenda by moving a budget reconciliation package that would include about $100 billion in funding to secure the U.S.-Mexico border, reforms to expand oil and gas drilling and a substantial increase in defense spending.

Senate Republican Whip John Barrasso (Wyo.) said that House Republicans â€œright nowâ€ are â€œnot able to move at the level weâ€™d like them to move.â€

Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), however, told reporters Tuesday afternoon that the plan is still for the House, not the Senate, to move forward on a budget package that would encompass border security, energy, defense and tax legislation.

â€œThe Senate will not take the lead. Weâ€™ll take the lead. Weâ€™re right on schedule,â€ he said.

Meanwhile, caught between the debt and their tax base, Republicans are considering novel ways to account for the cost of their legislative agenda as a budget cut impasse looks set to hamstring early moves on their tax bill. Known as working from the â€œcurrent policy baseline,â€ the accounting method would let Republicans sweep nearly $5 trillion of debt under the rug â€” likely producing a much smaller and more palatable number by which the tax legislation would add to the deficit.Â 

â–ª The Hill: Trump is expected to sign an executive order today banning transgender athletes from competing in girlsâ€™ and womenâ€™s sports, the latest in a string of executive actions from the new administration taking aim at LGBTQ rights.

â–ª The Hill: A federal judge in Washington, D.C., will hear a request today from three anonymous transgender inmates to block Trumpâ€™s executive order mandating that incarcerated transgender women be housed in male facilities.

â–ª The Hill: Trump is reportedly eyeing an executive order to dismantle the Education Department, which has placed dozens of staffers on leave in what their union says is a move to encourage resignations.

â–ª The Hill: Diversity, equity and inclusion proponents are scrambling to find ways to counter Trump as he moves to dismantle some of the programs and policies intended to bolster their movement.Â 

â–ª The Hill: Trump withdrew the U.S. from the United Nations Human Rights Council and UNESCO, the United Nations Educations, Scientific and Cultural Organization, on Tuesday with the stroke of his pen.

The big question plaguing Democrats since their grueling loss in November: Who is the party leader? Itâ€™s a question party operatives have encountered trouble in answering. And with Trump taking a series of swift actions to remake the government, finding the answer is imperative. This week, Democrats took the first major step in their rebuilding effort when they elected Ken Martin as the new Democratic National Committee chair. Right out of the gate, Martin signaled the party would be taking a more forceful approach to Trump. But Democrats quietly expressed concern that Martin, who is relatively unknown, would not be enough.

â€œDemocrats are craving true leaders, who can emerge by being louder and using all the emotions,â€ said Tracy Sefl, a veteran Democratic consultant. â€œThe crisis weâ€™re in demands leaders who will talk with the passion of someone who calls into sports radio shows. Show us youâ€™re fighting like hell for our team, while we risk losing badly with precious time left.â€Â 

â–ª The New York Times: New York lawmakers may give Gov. Kathy Hochul (D) more time to schedule special elections, a move backed by House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) because it could keep a key House seat vacant for months.

â–ª NOTUS: Democrats are finally coming to a plan to counter Trump. Maybe.

ELSEWHERE

Â© The Associated Press | Efrem LukatskyÂ 

RARE MINERALS: Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov on Tuesday slammed Trumpâ€™s proposal for continued U.S. military aid to Ukraine in exchange for access to its valuable mineral rights. â€œIf we call things as they are, this is a proposal to buy help â€” in other words, not to give it unconditionally, or for some other reasons, but specifically to provide it on a commercial basis,â€ Peskov told reporters.

The minerals deal is an idea previously suggested by Republican senators and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, who has sought to appeal to Trumpâ€™s dealmaker persona to ensure Washingtonâ€™s support of Kyiv under Russiaâ€™s incursion â€” which has claimed the lives of an estimated 45,000 Ukrainian troops.Â 

A senior Ukrainian official told The Washington Post that Zelenskyâ€™s team is â€œready to sign documents about joint agreementsâ€ and that â€œhaving a strategic U.S. interest in Ukraine is a key component to our security in the future.â€

Still, Kyivâ€™s supporters remain nervous that Trump may try to force a ceasefire favorable to Russian President Vladimir Putin. As Moscow makes steady battlefield gains, Putin has shown no interest in a truce without significant territorial gains and a promise that Ukraine will never join NATO.

â–ª The Guardian: Greenland plans to ban foreign political donations over fears about potential interference in its forthcoming elections after attracting Trumpâ€™s interest.

â–ª Reuters: Japanâ€™s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba will visit the White House this week.

â–ª NPR: Swedenâ€™s worst mass shooting leaves at least 11 dead at an adult education center.

â–ª The Wall Street Journal: The Salvadoran mega-prison offering to take Americaâ€™s worst criminals. Lockup currently houses thousands of members of gangs that terrorized the Central American country for decades.

OPINIONÂ 

â–  Elon Musk is president, by Jonathan Lemire, contributing writer, The Atlantic.

â–  To save democracy, start filing cases, by Peter M. Shane, guest essayist, Washington Monthly.

THE CLOSER

Â© The Associated Press | NASA

And finally â€¦ ğŸª¨ Mark your calendars for Dec. 22, 2032. Thatâ€™s when a football field-sized asteroid could hurtle toward Earth and potentially crash into the planet, according to scientists.

But donâ€™t worry quite yet â€” the chance of impact is currently at 1 percent, and the longer scientists study the asteroidâ€™s path through space, the lower those odds are expected to get. Spreading the word of the asteroid, experts said, is mainly part of an effort to direct resources to study the space rock before it moves out of the view of telescopes.

Kelly Fast, the acting planetary defense officer for NASAâ€™s Planetary Defense Coordination Office, told NPR itâ€™s important to keep the matter in perspective.

â€œThe worldwide community is watching this and taking notice that itâ€™s reached this threshold,â€ she said. â€œWe do want to keep an eye on it. We do take it seriously, but we want to put it in perspective â€¦ Thereâ€™s still a very low probability that it would even impact the Earth at all.â€

We want to hear from you! Email: Alexis Simendinger (asimendinger@thehill.com) and Kristina Karisch (kkarisch@thehill.com). Follow us on social platform X: (@asimendinger and @kristinakarisch) and suggest this newsletter to friends!Â

data.title: Trump turns up the heat on public broadcasters
data.description:
President Trump and his allies are showing renewed vigor as they set their crosshairs on a longtime target for the right: public media.Â 

Recent moves by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and Republican lawmakers scrutinizing outlets like NPR and PBS over perceptions of liberal bias and taxpayer funding have highlighted the GOPâ€™s willingness to use the power of the federal government to make life difficult for outlets Trump feels have treated him unfairly.Â 

Trump has telegraphed plans to take on NPR for years, celebrating an essay from a former editor who publicly accused the outlet of bias last year by vowing to give it no more public funding and describing it as a scam.

With Trump now in the White House, allies have begun turning up the heat.

â€œTrump has aggressively targeted these organizations and now has the administrative muscle to do something about it,â€ said Tobe Berkovitz, a Boston University professor who specializes in the media.

The effort was punctuated last week in a letter from FCC Chair Brendan Carr to NPR and PBS leadership saying he planned to launch an investigation into member stations airing sponsorships.

Federal law prohibits public broadcasters from selling commercial sponsorships, but the outlets are allowed to broadcast public underwriting spots paid for by private donors.

The majority of NPRâ€™s and PBSâ€™s funding comes from private sponsorships and user contributions. The outlets also receive a smaller portion of their financing from the federal government and member stations.

NPR said in a statement to The Hill it is â€œconfident any review of our programming and underwriting practices will confirm NPRâ€™s adherence to these rules.â€

GOP lawmakers are putting a spotlight on NPR and PBS, too.

On Monday, a House subcommittee on government efficiency headed by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.) called on the outletsâ€™ executives to testify at a hearing concerning â€œthe systemically biased news coverage produced on behalf of federally funded radio and TV stations.â€

â€œSince its inception, NPR has collaborated with local nonprofit public media organizations to fill critical needs for news and information in Americaâ€™s communities,â€ NPR said in a statement to The Hill. â€œWe welcome the opportunity to discuss the critical role of public media in delivering impartial, fact-based news and reporting to the American public.â€

The latest targeting of public broadcasters comes as the White House has embraced more social and independent media platforms in lieu of mainstream news outlets, several of which the president decried or sued along the campaign trial.

Some observers pointed to a line in Carrâ€™s letter that questioned â€œwhy Congress should continue sending taxpayer dollars to NPR and PBS given the changes in the media marketplace since the passage of the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.â€

Ellen Goodman, a professor of media policy and law at Rutgers, noted that comment was a telling one.

â€œThe public broadcasters have struggled for a long time with diversifying their audiences not just in terms of age but across all demographics,â€ Goodman said. â€œStill, itâ€™s clear from Carrâ€™s rhetoric there certainly is an interest in going after media whose content is objectionable, and that presents a big First Amendment problem.â€

Several journalists at NPR and member stations declined to comment on the record when contacted by The Hill. The White House did not respond to a request for comment.

NPR has long been on the receiving end of attacks from conservatives and allies of the current administration. It famously left the social platform X after owner Elon Musk attached an official â€œstate mediaâ€ label to its account.

Musk, who now leads Trumpâ€™s Department of Government Efficiency, on Monday reiterated calls to â€œdefund NPR,â€ saying the outlet â€œshould survive on its own.â€

FCC Commissioner Anna M. Gomez, who was nominated to her position by former President Biden in 2023, criticized Carrâ€™s posture.

Â â€œThis appears to be yet another Administration effort to weaponize the power of the FCC,â€ sheÂ wrote in a postÂ on social media responding to Carrâ€™s letter. â€œThe FCC has no business intimidating and silencing broadcast media.â€

It is unclear how far the Trump administration will go in its efforts toward NPR and other public media outlets, though some are anticipating it could reach a fever pitch.

â€œNPR opens itself up to criticism from people who donâ€™t want them around because theyâ€™re getting some government funding,â€ said Juan Williams, who worked at the public broadcaster for a decade before becoming a senior political analyst at Fox News.

â€œMy concern is now the Trump people are saying they donâ€™t even think they should have [private] underwriters because they see that as a way to absolutely kill them off.â€

data.title: Bottom Line: NFL and MLB sign PhronesisDC
data.description:

data.title: DeepSeekâ€™s rise raises data privacy, national security concerns
data.description:
The emergence of a newly popular artificial intelligence (AI) model from Chinese startup DeepSeek is raising national security and data privacy concerns for the U.S., not unlike those that spurred a ban on TikTok last month.Â Â Â 

While the Chinese AI modelâ€™s rise has investors worried about the necessity of American AI companiesâ€™ massive infrastructure spending, it has experts concerned for other reasons â€” namely the potential ability for the Chinese government to access and manipulate the platformâ€™s data.Â 

â€œThe privacy policy explicitly says that it collects information and secures it on servers in China. Any data that youâ€™re putting into DeepSeek, that is through the app or through a DeepSeek model available on the internet, that is collected and goes to China,â€ said Oliver Roberts, co-head of the AI Practice Group at law firm Holtzman Vogel.Â 

DeepSeek exploded onto the scene last month with its R1 model, quickly rising to the top of Appleâ€™s App Store and overtaking OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT. Â 

The modelâ€™s rapidly growing popularity, along with the Chinese AI startupâ€™s impressive claims about its development, sent investors into a panic about American-made AI, sparking a mass sell-off in the tech sector. Â 

DeepSeek claims to have built the R1 model using just a few thousand reduced-capacity chips from Nvidia, for a measly overall cost of $5.6 million. This contradicted the assumption of American firms that massive investment in AI infrastructure is necessary to advance the technology.Â 

Microsoft plans to invest $80 billion in data centers throughout 2025, while Meta will nearly double its spending on capital expenditures this year to between $60 billion and $65 billion.Â 

OpenAI, Oracle and SoftBank have also taken the lead on the Trump administrationâ€™s new Stargate project that plans to invest up to $500 billion in AI infrastructure in the next four years. Â 

Even as worries abound about what DeepSeek means for American-made AI, other concerns are arising from the Chinese startupâ€™s privacy policies. Â 

DeepSeek automatically collects data on IP addresses, key stroke patterns and cookies, which is stored on â€œsecure servers located in the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China.â€ Â 

This raises the prospect that U.S. user data could end up in the hands of the Chinese government, which can legally compel Chinese companies to turn over data, not unlike U.S. law enforcement.Â 

This data could then be used to profile Americans or manipulate algorithms to target propaganda, Roberts suggested. Â 

He cautioned that businesses using DeepSeek could risk opening up their trade secrets to China, which has a poor track record on intellectual property protections.Â 

DeepSeek also currently lacks numerous privacy controls that exist in most other AI models, noted Rob Lee, chief of research and head of staff at SANS Institute, a cybersecurity firm. Â 

â€œUnlike OpenAI â€” which, while imperfect, has a stronger commitment to privacy and anonymization â€” DeepSeek collects and indefinitely stores massive amounts of user data in China, without clear anonymization measures,â€ Lee said in a statement.Â 

â€œThatâ€™s a significant risk, not just from a security standpoint, but in terms of potential data misuse, regulatory concerns, and overall trust in AI systems,â€ he added.Â 

The Hill has reached out to DeepSeek for comment.

Some companies have sought to take advantage of the open-source nature of DeepSeekâ€™s models to alleviate these concerns. Perplexity AI has made DeepSeekâ€™s R1 available but is hosting the model â€œexclusively in US & EU data centersâ€ so that â€œyour data never leaves Western servers.â€Â 

â€œI think itâ€™s really important to distinguish between the DeepSeek products, which is their app, website and their API, and then the open-source model weights,â€ Dmitry Shevelenko, Perplexityâ€™s chief business officer, told The Hill.Â 

â€œThe product is very dangerous and scary because they are not only sending all your prompts and questions to China, theyâ€™re doing scary tracking of your activity on your device as well that they can get access to,â€ he continued.Â 

â€œThe flip side is the model weights, which are open source,â€ Shevelenko added. â€œWe were able to take those and put them ourselves in a U.S. data center and quickly make that available in Perplexity as one of the models.â€Â 

The national security and data privacy concerns emerging around DeepSeek echo the worries that surrounded TikTok and ultimately led Congress to pass a law requiring its China-based parent company ByteDance to sell the app or face a ban.Â 

The law received wide bipartisan support amid concerns the Chinese government could access U.S. user data and potentially manipulate the content they see on the popular video-sharing platform. More than 170 million Americans use the app, according to TikTok.Â 

The ban was set to go into effect Jan. 19. However, it is currently on hold after President Trump barred enforcement for 75 days amid efforts to reach a deal to keep the app available in the U.S.Â 

Several lawmakers have already voiced concerns to the new Trump administration about DeepSeek.Â 

In a letter to national security adviser Mike Waltz last week, Reps. John Moolenaar (R-Mich.) and Raja Krishnamoorthi (D-Ill.) urged him to consider prohibiting the federal government from acquiring AI systems based on Chinese models, like DeepSeek. They also asked the administration to restrict the use of these models in critical infrastructure.Â 

Moolenaar and Krishnamoorthi are the top lawmakers on the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).Â 

â€œ[I]t is clear we are at an inflection point in the AI market where PRC AI systems are increasingly available for use in the United States,â€ they wrote, using an abbreviation for Peopleâ€™s Republic of China (PRC). â€œIt is imperative that we do not allow PRC AI systems to gain significant market share in the United States, while acquiring the data of U.S. users that only further enable the capabilities of the AI system.â€Â 

Amid speculation that DeepSeek managed to circumvent U.S. export controls to obtain more advanced chips, the lawmakers also called on Waltz to consider new restrictions on chip sales. Â 

Sens. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) and Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) similarly wrote to Howard Lutnick, Trumpâ€™s nominee to lead the Commerce Department, on Monday to urge him to close a â€œloopholeâ€ in the export control regime.Â 

â€œWith last weekâ€™s release of DeepSeekâ€™s R1, a Chinese artificial intelligence (AI) model that rivals leading U.S. models, we must confront the reality that the PRC challenge to our technological leadership is real, and missteps could seriously undercut our economic and national security,â€ they said.Â 

The U.S. developed an increasingly strict export control regime under the Biden administration in an effort to stymie Chinaâ€™s ability to develop artificial intelligence.Â 

DeepSeekâ€™s rise raises questions about the effectiveness of these controls and the state of the broader tech war between Washington and Beijing.Â 

â€œIf they have the ability to create models at the same level of complexity as ChatGPT and OpenAIâ€™s products 4.0 as well as o1, then that could put China on pace with the U.S. in terms of AI development, which has broader issues of Chinaâ€™s potential ability to create more advanced military equipment, weapons of mass destruction at a level we havenâ€™t seen,â€ Roberts added.Â 

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott (R) banned state officials from using Chinese-owned technology, like DeepSeek, on government-issued devices Friday, saying it â€œwill not allow the Chinese Communist Party to infiltrate our stateâ€™s critical infrastructure through data-harvesting AI and social media apps.â€

data.title: Republicans stare down massive deficits to extend Trump tax cuts
data.description:
Caught between the debt and their tax base, Republicans are considering some novel ways to account for the cost of their legislative agenda as disagreements over budget cuts look set to hamstring early moves on their tax bill.

Known as working from the â€œcurrent policy baseline,â€ the nonstandard accounting method would let Republicans sweep nearly $5 trillion of debt under the rug.

Using that baseline would keep the cost of extending expiring provisions of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act out of the billâ€™s budgetary score, but include the potential benefits of renewing those provisions. Doing so would likely produce a much smaller number by which the tax legislation would add to the deficit.

â€œThatâ€™s a $5 trillion question,â€ PwC tax expert and longtime Capitol Hill staffer Rohit Kumar told reporters in January, noting the policy baseline method could be used in either a one-bill or two-bill scenario for the Republican agenda.Â 

Jane Gravelle, senior specialist in economic policy at the nonpartisan Congressional Research Service (CRS), said using current policy baseline accounting would be a significant move.

â€œItâ€™s obviously a big deal,â€ Gravelle told The Hill. â€œEverything having to do with the debt is a big deal, because weâ€™ve got a big problem with the debt.â€

Despite President Trumpâ€™s preference for â€œone big, beautiful billâ€ with which to advance his agenda, Republicans may opt for two, after the House GOP failed to reach agreement on a top-line budget number at their retreat in Florida last month. Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) has said he wants to vote on a number by the end of February.

If the CBO were asked by Congress to score the costs of the tax legislation relative to a current policy baseline, the agency would do it, while also providing a score based on the primary accounting method, known as the â€œcurrent law baseline.â€

Current law baseline considers the 2017 Trump tax cuts as they are written into law, accounting for the expiration of provisions such as cuts to personal income tax rates.

The 2017 cuts were made temporary in the first place in order to satisfy the requirements of the budget reconciliation process, a legal workaround that sidesteps the need for 60 votes in the Senate and that Republicans are aiming to use once again.

Ultimately, itâ€™s a difference of assumption â€” but one with real consequences for the deficit, which ballooned to new highs after the pandemic and is a major concern for many Republicans. Total U.S. debt stock stands now at about $36 trillion, or 120 percent of annual gross domestic product.

On an annual basis, the budget deficit was $1.83 trillion in 2024; the government collected $4.92 trillion in revenue while spending $6.75 trillion, mostly on health and retirement insurance, defense and interest on the debt.

The CBO expects that annual shortfall to increase to $2.7 trillion by 2035, a number that doesnâ€™t include the tax cut extensions Republicans are seeking. Total U.S. debt stock will reach $59.3 trillion by 2035, CBO estimates.

Alex Muresianu, senior policy analyst with the Tax Foundation, called the distinction between the law and policy baselines a â€œgimmick.â€

â€œThe current law baseline, assuming that these tax cuts expire, looks a certain way and then if you assume a current policy baseline where everything is assumed to be extended, then the current policy baseline would be worse. Itâ€™s just sort of a gimmick in terms of the actual fiscal position of the United States,â€ he said.

Itâ€™s not unusual for the CBO to provide lawmakers with accounting projections based on assumptions that differ from current law, if lawmakers request that kind of information, though the agency differentiates between such analyses and considers the letter of the law to be the objective standard.

For example, the CBO published a cost estimate for the Biden administrationâ€™s Build Back Better in November 2021, which Republicans then asked the agency to modify assuming the policies were made permanent, rather than temporary. The estimates differed by an order of magnitude, jumping to $3 trillion from $367 billion.

â€œRight now they use the current law baseline, which says that in 2026 all these provisions will expire and so to restore them there will be a revenue cost,â€ Gravelle told The Hill.

Democrats have used policy baseline accounting projections in the past to advance their own agenda, Kumar noted.

â€œIs Congress going to have to officially account for the cost of extending the expiring provisions â€” just the expiring stuff â€” or are they going to take the view, as the Obama administration did in 2012, that that which is law today we should just assume [is] permanent?â€ he said.

â€œThis is a harder question to answer,â€ Kumar added.

Republican leadership is well aware of the challenges that lie ahead as it attempts to cut taxes and not explode the deficit.

â€œWe donâ€™t want to blow a hole in the deficit by extending the Trump-era tax cuts, for example,â€ Johnson said on Fox News on Monday. â€œBut weâ€™re definitely going to get that extended. Weâ€™ve got to find those savings.â€

Johnson said last week that the budget cuts Republicans had been considering amounted to a minimum rather than a maximum, but that minimum appears too low for the partyâ€™s deficit hawks. Rep. Ralph Norman (R-S.C.), a member of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, told The Hill that $500 billion worth of cuts was a â€œnonstarter.â€

Some unusual activity in recent months in the bond market, which is sensitive to the deficit, may be signaling further concerns about the national debt. As the Federal Reserve slashed short-term interest rates over the fall, longer term interest rates in the bond market have gone up, indicating investors want a greater return for their money. Analysts have described this divergence in rates as unusual.Â 

Ratings agency Fitch downgraded U.S. creditworthiness from AAA to AA+ in 2023 following a debt ceiling standoff between Democrats and Republicans. Republicans will need to raise the debt ceiling again this year.

data.title: Muskâ€™s expansive portfolio divides Trump world
data.description:
Elon Musk may be the most divisive man in Washington â€” and in President Trumpâ€™s White House.

In one camp stand Trump allies who see it as a matter of time before the president tires personally and professionally of Musk, who has been inescapable for the past week as he and staff for the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) have sought to seize control of various agencies.

The critics see a tech titan who is not accountable to anyone but Trump and stirs controversy, even with some Republicans.

In the other camp are Trump advisers who see Musk as helping to deliver on exactly what the president promised as a candidate.

â€œThis is what President Trump campaigned on,â€ White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Tuesday. â€œElon Musk is a highly respected, once-in-a-generation business leader who is volunteering his time to help make our federal government more efficient.â€

Muskâ€™s shadow looms over the White Houseâ€™s day-to-day business.

In separate exchanges over the past three days with the press, Trump was asked about Musk and his role in the government. Leavitt faced Musk questions during a brief Q&A with reporters on Monday amid uproar over the dismantling of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). Leavitt confirmed Musk is serving as aÂ special government employee.

Trump has been publicly supportive of Musk, and his advisers chafe at the suggestion that the tech titan is anything resembling a co-president.Â 

â€œElon canâ€™t do, and wonâ€™t do, anything without our approval,â€ Trump told reporters Monday. â€œAnd weâ€™ll give him the approval where appropriate, where not appropriate we wonâ€™t. â€¦ But he does have a good natural instinct, heâ€™s got a team of very talented people. Weâ€™re trying to shrink government, and he can probably shrink it as well as anyone else, if not better.â€

After Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz (D) posted on the social platform X that Musk â€œis a terrible president,â€ White House communications director Steven Cheung responded: â€œTim Walz is a cuck.â€

Musk has been at the center of Trumpâ€™s hacksaw to the federal government this week. He has been the main cheerleader forÂ gutting USAID. His team has been pushing for access to the Treasury Departmentâ€™sÂ payment system, and DOGE staff has been involved at the Small Business Administration and the Government Services Administration.

Muskâ€™s actions have led to protests outside the USAID building, outcry from Democrats and some unease from the public. AÂ Gallup pollÂ conducted Jan. 21-27 found 43 percent of Americans held a favorable view of Musk, compared to 47 percent who had an unfavorable view, and sustained bad news cycles centered on Musk could frustrate Trump.

â€œThis Elon thing is going to be over in like three months. Both of these guys want to be the center of attention,â€ one Republican donor who requested anonymity to speak freely told The Hill.

But where critics see Musk as an existential threat to government guardrails and a danger to Trump politically, his defenders view him as a revolutionary thinker with the work ethic to actually follow through on Trumpâ€™s campaign promises.

â€œThe only legitimate criticism that the Democrats can make is that President Trump has assembled the most highly competent, hardest working, and blazingly efficient Office of the President in American history,â€ senior White House aide Taylor Budowich posted on X. â€œThe agenda voters demanded WILL BE delivered.â€

Vanceâ€™s key role

With Musk soaking up significant attention, Vice President Vance has managed to fly somewhat under the radar in the early weeks of the new administration.

But it was Vance who played a critical part in helping some of Trumpâ€™s most controversial Cabinet nominees win over swing senators.

Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.) thanked Vance for â€œhis honest counselâ€ in deciding to support Robert F. Kennedy Jr.â€™s nomination to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.Â 

Sen. Todd Young (R-Ind.) also spoke with Vance as he eventually got to a â€œyesâ€ vote in favor of Tulsi Gabbardâ€™s nomination to serve as director of national intelligence.Â 

White House officials argued Vanceâ€™s Senate connections will prove critical. He is well liked and respected by his former colleagues on the GOP side in particular, those officials said, and Vance has shown an ability to articulate Trumpâ€™s beliefs to lawmakers.

The trade war that wasnâ€™t

Trumpâ€™s trade war that wasnâ€™t with Mexico and Canada offered a lesson in how foreign leaders may try to navigate the next four years.

The president was poised to impose tariffs on both nations Tuesday, but they were delayed for a month after calls with leaders from both countries.Â 

Mexico announced it would send 10,000 soldiers to the U.S. border to crack down on fentanyl trafficking. Canada said it would appoint a czar to oversee efforts to stop the flow of fentanyl and would ratchet up its posture toward cartels.

Neither announcement was necessarily groundbreaking on its own, and Canada and Mexico in recent years have increased their efforts to cut down on migrants and drugs crossing the border. But the terms were enough to satisfy Trump, and the White House took a victory lap.

The lesson for foreign leaders? Even a small gesture to Trump can be enough to avert a damaging dispute.

Foreign leaders flock to White House

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had the honor of being the first foreign leader to meet Trump at the White House, but others arenâ€™t far behind.

Trump will host Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba at the White House on Friday.Â 

King Abdullah of Jordan is scheduled to meet with Trump on Tuesday. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer are also slated to visit Trump at the White House this month.Â 

The flurry of visits is reflective of the rush among foreign leaders to get on Trumpâ€™s good side and get a feel for what he may do on tariffs and foreign policy in the coming months.

data.title: Satisfaction with public education at record low: Gallup
data.description:
A Gallup poll released Wednesday found satisfaction with public education is at a record low as the Trump administration eyes shuttering the Department of Education. Â 

The annual Mood of the Nation survey found 24 percent are satisfied with public education while 73 percent are dissatisfied, the lowest since the poll began back in 2001. Â 

Only 16 percent of Republicans are somewhat or very satisfied with public education, compared to 30 percent of Democrats. Â 

The results come amid a fight about how public education will look in the future given the priorities of the Trump administration. Â 

The president is likely to take executive actions in the future to weaken the Department of Education, with the goal to one day completely eliminate it. Â 

â€œWeâ€™re ranked number 40 out of 40 schools, right? Weâ€™re ranked number one in cost per pupil, so we spend more per pupil than any other country in the world, and weâ€™re ranked at the bottom of the list. Weâ€™re ranked very badly. And what I want to do is let the states run schools,â€ Trump said in the Oval Office on Tuesday while speaking about ending the federal agency. Â 

Trump has also signed an executive order directing the federal government to prioritize and help states utilize federal funds to assist school choice programs. Â

data.title: Republicans scramble for solutions on Trump legislative agenda after punting vote
data.description:
House Republicans are scrambling to find a solution to internal disagreements over their plan to pass President Trumpâ€™s sprawling agenda, an effort that kicked into high gear after leadership was forced to punt a key vote this week â€” and as the Senate inches closer to moving ahead with its alternative plan.

During a late-night meeting in the Capitol Tuesday night, lawmakers â€”Â including hardline conservatives, moderates and members of leadership â€”Â discussed potentially moving a five-year reconciliation package, to advance Trumpâ€™s agenda, three sources told The Hill, floating an abridged piece of legislation as the conference remains at odds over spending cuts.

Throughout the budget reconciliation process Republicans have been operating under the assumption that the package full of Trumpâ€™s priorities â€” which include expensive tax extensions and exemptions â€” would last for 10 years. Shortening that timeframe would drastically lower the projected cost of the proposal in scoring.

A reduction in the overall price tag could help gin up support among hardline conservatives, many of whom are demanding that the package be deficit neutral â€” a goal that would be more attainable with a lower cost. But it would also shorten the lifespan of the extended tax cuts, a fact that could frustrate some members. Trump has said he wants to make the tax cuts permanent.

One source said that leadership plans to present the five-year idea to lawmakers during their House GOP conference meeting Wednesday morning, though it remains unclear if it would muster enough support in the slim majority.

Johnson did not take a position on the five-year idea, another source said.

A diverse group of lawmakers were present for the meeting, including Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), House Majority Leader Steve Scalise (R-La.), House Ways and Means Committee Chair Jason Smith (R-Mo.), House GOP Conference Vice Chair Blake Moore (R-Utah) and Reps. Chip Roy (R-Texas), David Valadao (R-Calif.), Ben Cline (R-Va.) and Kevin Hern (R-Okla.), according to one of the sources.

While the viability of the five-year framework remains an open question, the fact that it was floated at all underscores the immense pressure House Republicans are under to move forward on a budget resolution that will include Trump priorities on tax, border enforcement, energy, and more â€” but will require near unanimity in the razor-thin GOP majority to advance.

The special budget reconciliation process will allow Republicans to circumvent the 60-vote threshold in the Senate and move the bill without needing support from Democrats.

GOP leaders had aimed to complete a blueprint at their Florida retreat last week and take an initial step to mark up the budget resolution in committee this week, but those seeking steep cuts derailed that plan by balking at an initial budget resolution proposalÂ that featured a $500 billion tax cut floor. While leaders saw that as simply a starting point, fiscal hawks wanted commitments for much higher levels of cuts, with some seeking overall cuts of $2 trillion to $5 trillion.

Though Johnson earlier on Tuesday had said that movement on the resolution in committee might still be possible, Scalise left the meeting saying Republicans would not be able to move on the markup this week.

â€œNo,â€ Scalise succinctly responded when asked if House Republicans could mark up a budget resolution this week.

â€œThatâ€™s what weâ€™re focused on,â€ when pressed on if the key vote could happen next week.

Scalise said that Republicans had raised the floor for cuts from what leaders presented at the House GOP retreat last week, which included ranges of cuts that each committee was tasked to come up with to offset the cost of priorities in the bill.Â 

â€œWe have gone back to each committee to increase those numbers,â€ Scalise said, signaling that $1 trillion in cuts was realistic.

But the tricky part is making sure the numbers are right â€” and that the votes are still there.

Scalise that there will now be more â€œfront-loadingâ€ of the work that leaders had initially expected would take place weeks from now in order to get agreement on the first step in the budget resolution.

â€œRight now weâ€™re doing is getting a lot more into the details of what the committees would have been doing in March, but weâ€™re doing it now in the context of putting together the budget,â€ Scalise said. â€œThe Budget Committee wants to be comfortable with numbers that they vote on to give the committees, and they werenâ€™t. So weâ€™re reworking it, but weâ€™re reworking it by also working with the committees to make sure they can pass those â€”Â  those numbers.

Reacting to the struggles on the House side, Senate Budget Committee Chair Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) is set to brief senators on WednesdayÂ about moving first on a budget resolution for an initial, skinny bill that would address border security, energy and defense. That measure would later be followed by a package extending the 2017 Trump tax cuts.

â€œWe do have a bill ready to go here and Sen. Graham is going to be briefing the conference on that tomorrow at lunch,â€ Senate Republican Whip John Barrasso (Wyo.) told reporters on Tuesday.

Fear of a Senate alternative appears to be firing up House Republicans to try to find a solution to their internal conflict.

â€œTheyâ€™re worried about the Senate jamming them on a bill from the Senate, and the Senate would be a light one, it wouldnâ€™t include the tax extension,â€ one source said when discussing the Tuesday night House Republican meeting.

Johnson earlier on Tuesday insisted that the House will be spearheading the Trump agenda bill and shut down the idea of the Senate moving first.

â€œThe Senate will not take the lead,â€ Johnson said earlier on Tuesday. â€œWeâ€™ll take the lead. Weâ€™re right on schedule.â€
